document.docAuthor: Quicke, Donald L. J., Hogan, James E., Bennett, Andrew M. R., Broad, Gavin R. & Butcher, Buntika A.
document.masterDocTitle: Partial revision of the Indo-Australian braconine wasp genus Gammabracon Quicke (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) with descriptions of new species from Indonesia (Mollucas), Malaysia, Philippines and Thailand

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Partial revision of the Indo-Australian braconine wasp genus Gammabracon Quicke (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) with descriptions of new species from Indonesia (Mollucas), Malaysia, Philippines and Thailand

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Iphiaulax abjectus Cameron and Strand, 1912: 39
(in Strand, 1912 ) ( nec.
Iphiaulax abjectus Cameron, 1887: 259
).

subSubSection.paragraph:
HOLOTYPE : Female MALAYSIA ( SARAWAK ): â€˜Lundu, Sarawak , Borneo 21/20 8.00 Micholitzâ€™, â€˜
Iphiaulax abjectivus Sreand
det. Cam. & Strd.â€™, â€˜
Iphiaulax abjectivus Cam.
typeâ€™. (Berlin)
Additional features . Antenna with 65 flagellomeres; width of head:width of face:height of eye = 2.0:1.05:1.0.

caption.paragraph:
Figure 19.
Gammabracon abjectivus
sp. nov. , holotype female. (a) Habitus, dorsal view. (b) Head dorsal view. (c) Head and anterior mesosoma, lateral view. (d) Face, frontal view. (e) Scutellum. (f) Forefemur and tibia.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments . This species appears indistinguishable from
G. forticarinata ( Cameron, 1902 )
,
G. nigriseta (Enderlein, 1920)
and
G. rugifrons ( Smith, 1858 )
based on the few, old specimens available. These four species can be distinguished from all other species of
Gammabracon
by combination of the following characters: (1) wing membrane uniformly dark brown; (2) 4th metasomal tergite without strong carination.
Additional fresh material is required prior to any taxonomic decision on the relative status of these four species.

Unplaced specimens aff.
G. abjectivus , forticarinata
,
nigriseta
and
rugifrons

caption.paragraph:
Figure 20.
Gammabracon abjectivus
sp. nov. , holotype female. (a) Central part of forewing. (b) Base of hind wing. (c) Metasomal tergites 2â€“4.
